pageData.text: The relationship between pressure and velocity in <button class='glossary-text'>ideal fluids</button> is described quantitatively by Bernoulli’s equation. For an ideal fluid that is incompressible with no <button class='glossary-text'>viscosity</button>, Bernoulli’s equation can be considered to be a statement of the conservation of energy for fluid flow. An application of Bernoulli’s equation to a siphon results in <button class='glossary-text'>Torricelli’s theorem</button> for fluid flow out of a hole in a reservoir. In this lab, you will investigate Torricelli’s theorem for fluid flow.

pageData.text: Deep sea exploration has been limited, in part, because of pressure. For every 10 meters traveled deeper into the ocean, there is an additional 6.47kg (14.27 lbs.) of pressure on each square inch of surface. At approximately 3000m (1.86 mi) that would feel like an SUV was pushing down on your head1. The deepest part of the ocean is about 11,000 meters (6.8 miles). How is it possible that animals are able to live under such pressure?

Animals that live in the deepest parts of the oceans are able to do so because they don’t have lungs, air bladders, or gas-filled cavities. An example of an animal that has adapted to living under extreme pressure is the sea cucumber Enypniastes eximia (also known as the headless chicken monster). This sea cucumber spends much of its time feeding on the ocean floor, however, it is able to travel as much as 1,000 m (3,300 ft) up into the water column. Although humans may be able to learn about how to survive living under pressure by studying animals like the sea cucumber, animals adapted to deep sea pressures are difficult to study as they may experience metabolic distress when brought to the surface.

1Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. (2023). Why is pressure different in the ocean?
https://www.whoi.edu/know-your-ocean/did-you-know/why-is-pressure-different-in-the-ocean/

Image by NOAA Office of Ocean Exploration and Research, Exploring Deep-sea Habitats off Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
https://oceanexplorer.noaa.gov/okeanos/explorations/ex1811/logs/nov7/welcome.html

pageData.desc: A cone-shaped, semi-translucent sea cucumber floating vertically in the water with the narrow part of its body at the bottom.
pageData.altText: A cone-shaped, semi-translucent sea cucumber floating vertically in the water with the narrow part of its body at the bottom.

pageData.subTitle: Bernoulli’s Principle
pageData.text: Bernoulli’s equation quantitatively describes a relationship between pressure and velocity in . It was named after the Swiss scientist Daniel Bernoulli (1700–1782). For an ideal fluid that is incompressible with no , the , , and of the fluid is constant.

The kinetic energy of the fluid is stored as , Ps, a measure of the pressure at a given point in the fluid, and as , PD. Dynamic pressure is calculated as shown in Equation 1 using fluid density, ρ (kg/m 3) and fluid velocity, v, (m/s).

pageData.altText: Equation 1: P sub D equals begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared

pageData.text: Dynamic pressure measures the kinetic energy per unit volume of a particle in the fluid; a fluid will not have dynamic pressure unless it is moving. Pressure is a scalar quantity, which is proportional to the magnitude of the force acting perpendicular to a surface area. The SI unit for pressure is the pascal (Pa), named after the French mathematician and physicist Blaise Pascal (1623–1662). The SI unit of static pressure and dynamic pressure is the pascal (1Pa = 1N/m2).

In , the path of imaginary particles suspended in a fluid and carried along with the fluid is a streamline. When the flow rate is steady, the fluid is moving but the streamlines are fixed. A relatively high rate of fluid flow occurs when streamlines cluster together; where streamlines are spread out, the rate of fluid flow is relatively low. If there is no change in potential energy along a streamline, Bernoulli’s equation indicates the total energy along that streamline is constant and there is a balance between static and dynamic pressure. This relationship is represented mathematically as Bernoulli’s equation, shown in Equation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: P sub s plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared equals constant

pageData.text: If the depth of the fluid changes but the density remains constant, there will be a change in the . The relationship for pressure at a depth in a fluid must be included in Bernoulli’s equation to account for the change of depth of the fluid, as shown in Equation 3. The subscript 1 is the first fluid depth, or elevation 1, and subscript 2 is the second fluid depth, or elevation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: P sub 1 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared sub 1 plus rho g h sub 1 equals P sub 2 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared sub 2 plus rho g h sub 2

pageData.text: In Equation 3, P1 and P2 measure absolute pressure, which is equal to plus .

The general energy relationship represented by Equation 3 is a most useful equation in <button class='glossary-text'>fluid mechanics</button>, but there are restrictions in its applicability summarized by these conditions.

text: There is a steady rate of fluid flow.
Density is constant.
The fluid is incompressible.
No work is done on or by the fluid.
No heat is transferred to or from the fluid.
No change occurs in the internal energy.
The equation relates the states at two points along a single streamline, not the conditions on two different streamlines.

pageData.text: Bernoulli’s equation can be derived by integrating <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s second law of motion</button> along a streamline using gravitational and pressure forces as the forces acting on a fluid element. Given that any energy exchanges result from conservative forces, the total energy along a streamline is constant and is transferred between potential energy and <button class='glossary-text'>kinetic energy</button>. Bernoulli’s equation also can be considered to be a statement of the conservation of energy principle for fluid flow.

There are a number of devices and situations that can be analyzed using Bernoulli’s equation. One example is fluid flow through a nozzle. Fluid enters the nozzle at low speed, accelerates, and exits the nozzle at atmospheric pressure. To find the pressure of the fluid when it enters the nozzle, apply Bernoulli’s equation between entry and exit points and then calculate the unknown pressure. Assume the change in elevation between the entry and exit points is zero.

Airplane wings are constructed so air flow over the top of the wing, where the surface is longer, is greater than under the wing. The pressure on top of the wing is therefore less than the pressure under the wing, creating a net upward force or lift. Sails also have the characteristic shape of a wing. The pressure on the front side of a sail is lower than the pressure on the back of the sail, resulting in a forward force.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A sailboat with a large vertical sail unfurled.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A sailboat with a large vertical sail unfurled.

options.text: non-viscous, frictionless, and incompressible
viscous, frictionless, and incompressible
able to be heated to high degrees without boiling
characterized by variable density
sticky and contains heat

If there is no change in potential energy along a streamline, Bernoulli’s equation indicates the total energy along that streamline is constant and there is a balance between static and dynamic pressure.

pageData.subTitle: Torricelli’s Theorem
pageData.text: Another application is a siphon, where Bernoulli’s equation is used to find the velocity of a fluid as it exits the drain of a reservoir. Fluid flows from a higher level to a lower level, and Bernoulli’s equation is applied between the reservoir surface and the exit point. Pressure at both points is atmospheric and, because the reservoir is very large, the velocity of the fluid in the reservoir is negligible. Use these conditions in Equation 3 to solve for the rate at which fluid flows from the drain, v2 given in Equation 4. The reservoir has fluid at elevation 1, H, and the drain is at elevation 2, a distance of h below H or a distance of H – h above the ground.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A bottle with water (reservoir), with fluid level at H and draining at h, and the range from the bottle to where the water impacts the ground
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A bottle with water (reservoir), with fluid level at H and draining at h, and the range from the bottle to where the water impacts the ground
Equation 3: P sub 1 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared sub 1 plus rho g h sub 1 equals P sub 2 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared sub 2 plus rho g h sub 2

pageData.text: Apply conditions P1 = P2 and v1 = 0; also let h1 = H, h2 = H − hρgH - ρg(H - h) = 1/2 ρv22Divide both sides by ρ, as the density of the fluid in the reservoir is constant, and multiply both sides by 2.2gh = v22Take the square root of both sides.

pageData.altText: Equation 4: v sub 2 equals begin square root 2 g h end square root

pageData.text: The relationship of <button class='resource-text'>Equation 4</button> is known as <button class='glossary-text'>Torricelli’s theorem</button>, Torricelli’s law, Torricelli’s equation, or Torricelli’s principle for fluid flow out of a hole in a reservoir. A streamline can be drawn from the top of the reservoir, where the total energy is known, to the exit point where the <button class='glossary-text'>static pressure</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>potential energy</button> are known but the <button class='glossary-text'>dynamic pressure</button> or flow velocity out of the reservoir is unknown.

Torricelli’s theorem provides a relationship between exit velocity of a fluid from a hole in a reservoir to the height of fluid above the hole. This relationship applies for an —an incompressible fluid with no resulting from an exchange of potential energy.

Bernoulli’s equation can be adapted for flow that is both unsteady and compressible. However, the assumption of an ideal fluid with no viscosity remains for both unsteady and compressible versions of the equation. This is studied in advanced <button class='glossary-text'>fluid mechanics</button>.

pageData.question: What does Torricelli’s theorem provide a relationship for?

options.text: between exit velocity of a fluid from a hole in a reservoir to the height of fluid above the hole
between temperature and velocity in ideal fluids
between mass and velocity in ideal fluids
between pressure and temperature in ideal fluids
a relationship between pressure and velocity in ideal fluids

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Torricelli’s theorem provides a relationship between exit velocity of a fluid from a hole in a reservoir to the height of fluid above the hole.

pageData.question: What does v2 represent in Torricelli’s theorem?

options.text: the rate at which fluid flows from the drain
the temperature of the ideal fluid
the mass of the ideal fluid
the elevation of the fluid reservoir
the elevation of the drain

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This variable represents the flow velocity of the liquid out of the reservoir.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The relationship of Equation 4 is known as Torricelli’s theorem, Torricelli’s law, Torricelli’s equation, or Torricelli’s principle for fluid flow out of a hole in a reservoir. A streamline can be drawn from the top of the reservoir, where the total energy is known, to the exit point where the static pressure and potential energy are known but the dynamic pressure or flow velocity out of the reservoir is unknown.

img.alt: Equation 4: v sub 2 equals begin square root 2 g h end square root

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The relationship of Equation 4 is known as Torricelli’s theorem, Torricelli’s law, Torricelli’s equation, or Torricelli’s principle for fluid flow out of a hole in a reservoir. A streamline can be drawn from the top of the reservoir, where the total energy is known, to the exit point where the static pressure and potential energy are known but the dynamic pressure or flow velocity out of the reservoir is unknown.

img.alt: Equation 4: v sub 2 equals begin square root 2 g h end square root

pageData.subTitle: Kinematics
pageData.text: From your study of kinematics, you learned the definition of motion terms and their relationships. Average velocity is defined as the net displacement, s, divided by the time interval, Δt.

pageData.altText: Equation 5: v sub average equals begin fraction s over delta t end fraction

pageData.text: The average velocity is the sum of the initial velocity, v0, and the final velocity, vf, divided by 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 6: v sub average equals begin fraction v sub f plus v sub 0 over 2 end fraction

pageData.text: For objects experiencing uniform acceleration, the acceleration is defined as the rate of change in velocity.

pageData.altText: Equation 7: a equals begin fraction delta v over delta t end fraction equals begin fraction v sub f minus v sub 0 over delta t end fraction

pageData.text: Rearranging the terms in Equation 7 to find the final velocity, vf, results in the relationship in Equation 8.

pageData.altText: Equation 8: v sub f equals v sub 0 plus a delta t

pageData.text: We can now derive a relationship between displacement, acceleration, and time.Solve Equation 6 for net displacement, s.s = vaverage ΔtSubstitute the definition of average velocity (Equation 6) into the relationship for net displacement s.s = [vf + v0/2]ΔtSubstitute the relationship in Equation 8 for final velocity, vf.s = [(v0 + aΔt ) + v0/2]Δt
Require the object be released from rest, v0 = 0. Substitute this condition into the relationship for net displacement, s.s = [aΔt/2]Δt
Rearrange the terms in the net displacement, s, relationship to get Equation 9.

pageData.altText: Equation 9: s equals begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction a begin paren delta t end paren squared

pageData.text: For objects experiencing uniform acceleration, the acceleration is defined as the rate of change in velocity. By definition, acceleration, a, is the derivative of velocity, v, with respect to time, t. Reverse this definition and integrate acceleration to find velocity. This results in the velocity-time kinematic equation of motion. Assume a constant acceleration.
Definition of acceleration ():a = dv/dt

Multiply by dt.d v = a dtIntegrate both sides.∫ vv0d v = ∫t0adtEvaluate the result at the limits.v − v0 = atRearrange terms to get .v = v0 + atBy definition, velocity is the derivative of displacement, s, with respect to time. Reverse this operation and integrate velocity to find displacement. The result is the displacement-time equation for constant acceleration.Definition of velocity:v = d s/dt

Multiply by dt.d s = v dtRearrange terms to get .d s = (v0 + at )dtIntegrate both sides.∫ss0d s = ∫t0(v0 + at )dtEvaluate the result at limits.s - s0 = v0t + 1/2 at 2Rearrange terms to get .s = s0 + v0t + 1/2 at 2

The fluid flow out of a reservoir is analogous to an object falling under the influence of gravity. The stream of fluid out of the exit point has noninitial velocity in the vertical, y, direction, and an initial velocity in the horizontal, x, direction. Then Equation 9 can be applied to the vertical drop of the stream of fluid where s = y and the acceleration is equal to the acceleration of gravity, a = g. Using these values in Equation 9 and solving for t gives Equation 10.

pageData.altText: Equation 10: t equals begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root

pageData.text: The velocity in the horizontal direction is the range, R, or the distance the fluid travels before hitting the ground divided by the time of Equation 10. Rearranging the terms of the horizontal velocity, vx allows you to find the range, R, as shown in Equation 11.

pageData.altText: Equation 11: R equals v sub x begin paren t end paren equals v sub x begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root

pageData.text: Substitute , , for vx to get a relationship for the range (Equation 12).

pageData.altText: Equation 12: R equals v sub x begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root equals begin square root 2 g h end square root begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root equals begin square root 4 h y end square root equals 2 begin square root h y end square root

pageData.text: This relationship will be used in Activity 1: Investigating <button class='glossary-text'>Torricelli’s Theorem</button> to calculate the range and then will be compared to the measured range of the stream of water from a plastic drink bottle at three different elevations (heights).

pageData.subTitle: Equation of Continuity
pageData.text: Fluid dynamics can be used to find the velocity of the flow of fluid in a given streamline. The basic equations of fluid flow are <button class='glossary-text'>conservation of mass</button> and conservation of momentum.

Analysis of fluid motion is completed in the same way as in solid mechanics by use of Newton’s laws of motion as moving fluids exert forces. The lift force on an aircraft is exerted by the air moving over the wing. A jet of water from a hose exerts a force on what it hits. But it may not be clear what mass of moving fluid should be used. Therefore, the Newton’s second law equation is stated as the rate of change of momentum.

The fluid must have a steady rate of fluid flow and be incompressible. To determine the rate of change of momentum for the fluid, consider a streamline (control volume) and apply Bernoulli’s equation. In this control volume, any change in momentum of the fluid within a control volume is due to the action of external forces on the fluid within the volume.

Consider the control volume as an imaginary surface enclosing a volume of fluid—either fixed or moving. To determine all forces acting on the surfaces of the control volume, solve the conservation laws in this control volume. The first conservation equation is the continuity equation (the law of conservation of mass), which states the sum of mass flow rates entering per unit time equals the sum of mass flow rates leaving per unit time.

pageData.altText: Equation 13: sigma delta m sub in equals sigma delta m sub out

pageData.text: The rate of change of the mass, Δm, can be calculated as the product of fluid density, ρ, and the change in volume, ΔV. An expression for change in volume, ΔV, is determined using the flow rate v, through a cross-sectional area, A, during the time interval Δt, as shown in Equation 14.

pageData.altText: Equation 14: delta m equals rho delta V equals rho v A delta t

pageData.text: The mass flow inside a control volume is constant.Δm1 = Δm2Substitute the relationship of Equation 14 at two points in the control volume, point 1 and point 2.

ρ v1 A 1 Δt = ρ v2 A 2 ΔtThe fluid density, ρ, and the time interval Δt will be the same interval between points resulting in the typical form of the continuity equation, the mathematical expression of the principle of for fluid flow. For a control volume that has a single inlet and a single outlet, the principle of conservation of mass states that, for steady-state flow, the mass flow rate into the volume must equal the mass flow rate out.

pageData.altText: Equation 15: A sub 1 v sub 1 equals A sub 2 v sub 2

pageData.text: where A1 is the cross-sectional area of volume 1 and v1 is the speed of fluid flow through volume 1. A 2 is the cross-sectional area of volume 2 and v2 is the speed of fluid flow through volume 2. See Figure 3.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A pipe that has a much wider opening on the left, labeled A1, than on the right, labeled A2. Several arrows point from A1 to A2, following the curved shape of the pipe as it narrows. The start of the arrows is labeled V1 and the end of the arrows is labeled V2.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A pipe that has a much wider opening on the left, labeled A1, than on the right, labeled A2. Several arrows point from A1 to A2, following the curved shape of the pipe as it narrows. The start of the arrows is labeled V1 and the end of the arrows is labeled V2.

pageData.text: In the extension activity, you will verify the equation of continuity using an online simulation.

pageData.question: What does the first conservation equation state?

options.text: The sum of mass flow rates entering per unit time equals the sum of mass flow rates leaving per unit time.
For steady-state flow, the density is related to the flow rate, and this must be equal the density flow rate out.
An object at rest remains at rest, and an object in motion remains in motion at constant speed and in a straight line unless acted on by an unbalanced force.
The sum of the flow potential differs around any closed system is zero.
Energy can be converted from one form to another with the interaction of heat and work.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The first conservation equation is the continuity equation (the law of conservation of mass), which states the sum of mass flow rates entering per unit time equals the sum of mass flow rates leaving per unit time.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of the investigation. To prepare, mark the edge of the bottle on the paper, cut the bottle holes bottles, and measure their heights. In Activity 1, fill the bottle, covering the hole with a finger. Then, remove your finger, record where the stream hits and measure the distance from bottle to hit point.  Then, reset the bottle and paper. After completing 4 trials, squeeze the bottle and record your observations. Then, change the bottle and repeat. After testing 3 bottles, calculate the vertical distance of water from each hole, the range of the water and the percent difference of the measured and calculated ranges. Finally, proceed to the extension activity.

After completing activity 1, in the extension activity, open the simulation, set up the pipes with the given parameters and observe the water flow rate. Then, record the gauge pressure, radius and speed. Next, set up the pipes with new parameters. After completing 3 trials, adjust the radius of the pipes. Finally, record the gauge pressure, radius and speed for all given radii.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Wear your safety goggles while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for this activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.
You will use the sharp knife to make holes in plastic drink bottles. This requires keeping safety in mind and taking precautions when using the knife.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation, and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

options.text: The fluid will not have dynamic pressure unless it is moving.
The fluid will have dynamic pressure when it is not moving.
The fluid will have dynamic pressure when it is moving and not moving.

The fluid will not have dynamic pressure since the kinetic energy per unit volume only applies to a particle in the fluid.

pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Watch the following video on camera recording techniques for physics investigations:

Create a work space. The lab involves water flowing out of a plastic bottle. You can perform the lab in any area where water can drain without causing damage to property, such as outside, indoors in or near a sink, or using a large dishpan. The surface needs to be flat.

Place a sheet of copy paper on the flat surface you will be using. Place a plastic bottle at one end of the paper, and use a marker to mark the location of the plastic bottle on the paper. This paper will be used to mark the point the stream of water lands when you remove your finger from a hole in the bottle during the activity. Repeat to mark the location of the bottle on each of the remaining 11 sheets of paper.
Use the sharp knife to make one hole at a different height as described below in each of the 3 plastic drink bottles.

1. On Bottle 1, make a small circular hole (~0.5 cm = 5 mm around) near the top of the large section of the bottle, not at or near the neck (see Figure 4). If you are using a standard 1-liter bottle, this hole will be approximately 14–15 cm from the bottom of the bottle.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Clear, plastic bottle with a small hole as described in Preparation Step 4a, outlined in blue marker
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Clear, plastic bottle with a small hole as described in Preparation Step 4a, outlined in blue marker

pageData.text:
1. On Bottle 2, make a small circular hole (~0.5 cm = 5 mm around) just above the middle of the bottle on the large diameter portion of the bottle. If you are using a standard 1-liter bottle, this hole will be approximately 10–11 cm from the bottom of the bottle.
  2. On Bottle 3, make a small circular hole (~0.5 cm = 5 mm around) near the bottom of the bottle. If you are using a standard 1-liter bottle, this hole will be approximately 3 cm from the bottom of the bottle.

Using the measuring tape or ruler, measure the height of the bottle from your flat surface to just under the neck of the bottle. In the Lab Notebook, record this value in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3. (The height of a standard 1-liter bottle is about 18.5 cm to just below the neck of the bottle.)
Measure the height of each hole from your flat surface to the center of the hole. Record these heights in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3, respectively.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: If you will not be videoing your lab, take a picture of your setup.

In Activity 1, you will test how far water will exit from holes at different heights along a plastic bottle.  You will then calculate the percent difference between the measured range of water and the theoretical range of the water based on <button class='glossary-text'>Torricelli's theorem</button>.

typeBefore.text: Note: Record measurements and make calculations using SI units with the correct number of significant digits.

typeBefore.title:
A
 Measurements Using Bottle 1: Hole Near the Top (14 steps)

pageData.text: Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 1 (hole near the top). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle. Place your first sheet of paper on the surface you are using for the lab.
Holding your finger over the hole, place your bottle on the bottle location you marked on the paper. Be prepared to watch the stream of water out of the hole. (It will happen very quickly.)

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start your video recording. Remove your finger from the hole, and mark where the stream of water first hits your piece of paper. You can use your finger to mark the point, or a volunteer helping you can place their finger at the point. Use the marker to mark the location on the paper. You do not need to allow the water to continue to run after it initially hits the paper.

Remove the bottle of water, and drain any excess water off the paper. Measure the distance between the location marked for the bottle and the point where the stream of water hit the paper. This is the range. Record this value in Data Table 1. (You may want to allow your sheet of paper to dry before making this measurement.)
Place the second sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.
Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 1 (hole near the top). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.
Place the third sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.
Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 1 (hole near the top). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.
Be sure your data is consistent, and repeat trials if needed.
Place the fourth sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.

Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 1 (hole near the top). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Place the cap tightly on the bottle. Place the bottle on the bottle location marked on the paper.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start your video recording. Remove your finger from the hole and observe what happens. Record your observations in Data Table 1. Try squeezing the bottle, and then record your observations.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Measurements Using Bottle 2: Hole Near the Middle (14 steps)

pageData.text: Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 2 (hole near the middle). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle. Place your fifth sheet of paper on the surface you will be using for the lab.
Holding your finger over the hole, place your bottle on the bottle location you marked on the paper. Be prepared to watch the stream of water out of the hole. (It will happen very quickly.)

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start your video recording. Remove your finger from the hole and mark where the stream of water first hits your piece of paper. You can use your finger to mark the point, or a volunteer helping you can place their finger at the point. Use the marker to mark the location on the paper. You do not need to allow the water to continue to run after it initially hits the paper.

Remove the bottle of water, and drain any excess water off the paper. Measure the distance between the location marked for the bottle and the point where the stream of water hit the paper. This is the range. Record this value in Data Table 2. (You may want to allow your sheet of paper to dry before making this measurement.)
Place the sixth sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.
Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 2 (hole near the middle). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.
Place the seventh sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.

Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 2 (hole near the middle). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle. Place the bottle on the bottle location marked on the paper.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.
Be sure your data is consistent, and repeat trials if needed.
Place the eighth sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.

Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 2 (hole near the middle). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Place the cap tightly on the bottle. Place the bottle on the bottle location marked on the paper.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start your video recording. Remove your finger from the hole and observe what happens. Record your observations in Data Table 2. Try squeezing the bottle, and then record your observation.

typeBefore.title:
C
 Measurements Using Bottle 3: Hole Near the Bottom (14 steps)

pageData.text: Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 3 (hole near the bottom). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle. Place your ninth sheet of paper on the surface you will be using for the lab.
Holding your finger over the hole, place your bottle on the bottle location you marked on the paper. Be prepared to watch the stream of water out of the hole. (It will happen very quickly.)

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start your video recording. Remove your finger from the hole, and mark where the stream of water first hits your piece of paper. You can use your finger to mark the point, or a volunteer helping you can place their finger at the point. Use the marker to mark the location on the paper. You do not need to allow the water to continue to run after it initially hits the paper.

Remove the bottle of water, and drain any excess water off the paper. Measure the distance between the location marked for the bottle and the point where the stream of water hit the paper. This is the range. Record this value in Data Table 3. (You may want to allow your sheet of paper to dry before making this measurement.)
Place the tenth sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.
Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 3 (hole near the bottom). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.
Place the eleventh sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.
Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 3 (hole near the bottom). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Do not put the cap on the bottle.
Repeat Steps 2 through 4.
Be sure your data is consistent, and repeat trials if needed.
Place the twelfth sheet of paper (with marked location for the bottle) on the surface you are using for the lab.

Hold your finger over the hole of Bottle 3 (hole near the bottom). Fill the bottle to the top with water. Place the cap tightly on the bottle. Place the bottle on the bottle location marked on the paper.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Start your video recording. Remove your finger from the hole, and observe what happens. Record your observations in Data Table 3. Try squeezing the bottle, and record your observations.

Calculate the vertical distance, y (H – h), of the water from the top of bottle, the hole near the top of the bottle, the hole near the middle of the bottle, and the hole near the bottom of the bottle. Record these values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3, respectively.

Using Equation 12, calculate the range for the hole near the top of the bottle, the hole near the middle of the bottle, and the hole near the bottom of the bottle. Record these range values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3, respectively.

pageData.altText: Equation 12: R equals 2 begin square root h y end square root

pageData.text: Calculate the percent difference between the measured and calculated range values. Record these values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3, respectively.

pageData.altText: Equation 16: percent difference equals begin bracket begin paren begin fraction vertical slash R sub measured minus R sub calculated vertical slash over begin paren begin fraction R sub measured plus R sub calculated over 2 end fraction end paren end paren times 100 end bracket

pageData.subTitle: Fluid Mechanics—Fluid Flow
pageData.text: In the Extension Activity, you will use an online simulation to observe the pressure and flow speed of water through pipes of different radii.

pageData.title: Outcomes
pageData.text: Determine the relationship between radius, speed, and pressure of fluids in motion using the Fluid Dynamics Lab*.

text: Verify the equation of continuity.

pageData.text: *The Fluid Flow Simulation is provided by The Physics Aviary (©2020 EBSCO Information Services).http://www.thephysicsaviary.com/index.html

text: Computer with internet access
Graphing program, i.e., Excel or Google Sheets

pageData.text: Access the Fluid Dynamics Lab simulation.
Click “Begin.”

Set the pipe on the left to the smallest radius allowed by the program. Set the pipe on the right to the greatest radius allowed by the program. Set the speed on the left equal to the highest value allowed by the program.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Watch as the fluid flows through the pipes. When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, take a screenshot. Include the screenshot in the Lab Notebook.
Record the (click on the gauge to enlarge), radius, and speed for the left pipe and for the right pipe in Data Table E1. Be sure to include the appropriate SI units.
Set the left pipe and the right pipe to the largest possible radius. Both pipes should have the same radius for this trial.

Set the pressure on the left pipe to be as large as possible. When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, record the gauge pressure (click on the gauge to enlarge), radius, and speed for the left pipe and for the right pipe in Data Table E2. Be sure to include the appropriate SI units.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a screenshot, and include the screenshot in the Lab Notebook.

Set the radius and speed of the right pipe to their highest values. The radius of the left pipe should be set to its highest value. For each trial, you will be lowering the radius of the right pipe by one click while keeping the values for the left pipe constant.

Lower the radius of the right pipe by one click. When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, record the gauge pressure (click on the gauge to enlarge), radius, and speed for the left pipe and for the right pipe in Test 1 Data Table E3. Be sure to include the appropriate SI units.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, take a screenshot. Include the screenshot in the Lab Notebook.

Lower the radius of the right pipe by another click. When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, record the gauge pressure (click on the gauge to enlarge), radius, and speed for the left pipe and for the right pipe in Test 2 of Data Table E3. Be sure to include the appropriate SI units.

Lower the radius of the right pipe by another click. When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, record the gauge pressure (click on the gauge to enlarge), radius, and speed for the left pipe and for the right pipe in Test 3 of Data Table E3. Be sure to include the appropriate SI units.

Lower the radius of the right pipe by another click. When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, record the gauge pressure (click on the gauge to enlarge), radius, and speed for the left pipe and for the right pipe in Test 4 of Data Table E3. Be sure to include the appropriate SI units.

Lower the radius of the right pipe by another click. When the fluid is flowing through both pipes, record the gauge pressure (click on the gauge to enlarge), radius, and speed for the left pipe and for the right pipe in Test 5 of Data Table E3. Be sure to include the appropriate SI units.
Use the simulation to explore other conditions.
Return the materials to equipment kit, and clean the area.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

Vertical Distance of Water from Top of Bottle, y = H-h (m)

header.text: Height of Hole above Flat Surface, h (m)
Vertical Distance of Water from Top of Bottle, y = H-h (m)

text: Review the data from Activity 1.  Explain whether the data verifies Torricelli’s theorem within an acceptable percent difference.

The speed of water in a hose increases from 1.96 m/s to 25.5 m/s as the water goes from the hose to the nozzle. Using Equation 3, calculate the pressure in the hose, given that the absolute pressure in the nozzle is 1.01 x 105 N/m2 (atmospheric) and assuming level, frictionless flow. Show your work.

A siphon is used to drain fluid from a higher-level reservoir to a lower-level reservoir.  If the drain is 6.75 m from the top of the higher-level reservoir, what is the velocity of the fluid as it exits the drain?  Show your calculations.

Explain your observation of the fluid flow for the trials where the cap was placed on the bottle before you removed your finger from the hole.  Compare your observations of this trial for each type of bottle.  Are they the same?

Explain your observation of the fluid flow when the cap was placed on the bottle, the hole was unobstructed, and the bottle was squeezed.  Compare your observations of squeezing the bottle for each type of bottle – are they the same?

text: Show your calculation of the speed of fluid through the right pipe in Extension Activity 1A using the continuity equation. (Equation 15)

Review the measured and calculated speeds of the fluid through the right pipe from Extension Activity 1A.  Explain whether these values verify the continuity equation to within an acceptable percent difference.
Show your calculation of the speed of fluid through the right pipe in Extension Activity 1B using the continuity equation. (Equation 15)

Review the measured and calculated speeds of the fluid through the right pipe from Extension Activity 1B.  Explain whether these values verify the continuity equation to within an acceptable percent difference.

Use spreadsheet software (Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets) to graph the radius of the left pipe squared versus the speed of the fluid in the right pipe.  Include a line of best fit and the equation of the line on the graph.  Upload the graph image below, not the spreadsheet file.

pageData.text: Click on the browse button to upload the file

text: What is the relationship between the slope of the line from Question 10 and the data in Data Table 6 as it pertains to the continuity equation?  Use this relationship to determine what the calculated slope of the line should be.
Calculate the percent difference between the graphed slope of the line from Question 10 and the calculated slope of the line from Question 10.
Does the data in Data Table 5 verify the continuity equation (within an acceptable percent difference)?

pageData.text: In order for your instructor to be able to open your video links, please select the "Save as PDF" option rather than "Print to PDF".

Equation 2: P sub s plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared equals constant
Equation 3: P sub 1 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared sub 1 plus rho g h sub 1 equals P sub 2 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v squared sub 2 plus rho g h sub 2
Figure 1: A sailboat with a large vertical sail unfurled.
Figure 2: A bottle with water (reservoir), with fluid level at H and draining at h, and the range from the bottle to where the water impacts the ground
Equation 4: v sub 2 equals begin square root 2 g h end square root
Equation 5: v sub average equals begin fraction s over delta t end fraction

pageData.content: Equation 6. Average velocity (in terms of change in velocity)
pageData.altText: Equation 6: v sub average equals begin fraction v sub f plus v sub 0 over 2 end fraction
Equation 7: a equals begin fraction delta v over delta t end fraction equals begin fraction v sub f minus v sub 0 over delta t end fraction
Equation 8: v sub f equals v sub 0 plus a delta t
Equation 9: s equals begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction a begin paren delta t end paren squared

pageData.content: Equation 10. Time for vertical drop of fluid
pageData.altText: Equation 10: t equals begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root

pageData.content: Equation 11. Range (horizontal displacement) of fluid in terms of horizontal velocity)
pageData.altText: Equation 11: R equals v sub x begin paren t end paren equals v sub x begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root

pageData.content: Equation 12. Range of fluid in terms of h
pageData.altText: Equation 12: R equals v sub x begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root equals begin square root 2 g h end square root begin square root begin fraction 2 y over g end fraction end square root equals begin square root 4 h y end square root equals 2 begin square root h y end square root
Equation 13: sigma delta m sub in equals sigma delta m sub out

pageData.content: Equation 14. Change in mass in terms of density and change in volume
pageData.altText: Equation 14: delta m equals rho delta V equals rho v A delta t
Equation 15: A sub 1 v sub 1 equals A sub 2 v sub 2

pageData.content: Figure 3.  Principle of conservation of mass in a pipe with different radii
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A pipe that has a much wider opening on the left, labeled A1, than on the right, labeled A2. Several arrows point from A1 to A2, following the curved shape of the pipe as it narrows. The start of the arrows is labeled V1 and the end of the arrows is labeled V2.

A map of the procedural workflow of the investigation. To prepare, mark the edge of the bottle on the paper, cut the bottle holes bottles, and measure their heights. In Activity 1, fill the bottle, covering the hole with a finger. Then, remove your finger, record where the stream hits and measure the distance from bottle to hit point.  Then, reset the bottle and paper. After completing 4 trials, squeeze the bottle and record your observations. Then, change the bottle and repeat. After testing 3 bottles, calculate the vertical distance of water from each hole, the range of the water and the percent difference of the measured and calculated ranges. Finally, proceed to the extension activity.

After completing activity 1, in the extension activity, open the simulation, set up the pipes with the given parameters and observe the water flow rate. Then, record the gauge pressure, radius and speed. Next, set up the pipes with new parameters. After completing 3 trials, adjust the radius of the pipes. Finally, record the gauge pressure, radius and speed for all given radii.

pageData.content: Figure 4. Placement of top bottle hole
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Clear, plastic bottle with a small hole as described in Preparation Step 4a, outlined in blue marker

Equation 16: percent difference equals begin bracket begin paren begin fraction vertical slash R sub measured minus R sub calculated vertical slash over begin paren begin fraction R sub measured plus R sub calculated over 2 end fraction end paren end paren times 100 end bracket

data.title: Atmospheric pressure
data.content: The pressure exerted by the weight of the atmosphere

data.title: Conservation of mass
data.content: The principle that mass cannot be created or destroyed

data.title: Dynamic pressure
data.content: A measure of the kinetic energy per unit volume of a particle in the fluid; only present when fluid is moving

data.title: Fluid mechanics
data.content: A branch of mechanics dealing with the properties of fluids in various states and with their reaction to forces acting upon them

data.title: Gauge pressure
data.content: The amount by which the pressure measured in a fluid exceeds that of the atmosphere

data.title: Ideal fluid
data.content: A fluid which is non-viscous, frictionless, and incompressible

data.title: Kinetic energy
data.content: The energy which a body possesses by virtue of being in motion

data.title: Newton's second law of motion
data.content: States that the net force is equal to mass times acceleration

data.title: Potential energy
data.content: The energy possessed by a body by virtue of its position relative to others

data.title: Static pressure
data.content: The pressure of a fluid on a body when the body is at rest relative to the fluid

data.title: Torricelli's theorem
data.content: A relationship between the exit velocity of a fluid from a hole in a reservoir to the height of fluid above the hole

data.title: Total mechanical energy
data.content: All the energy an object has because of its motion and its position

data.title: Viscosity
data.content: A measure of a fluid's resistance to flow
